Global

Methods

get(path, defaultValueopt, createNonExistingopt) → {object}

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 42

Retrieve data from the DD for a given dot-notated path into the DD. If no value/object is available at the path, you can optionally create the value/object at that path using a provided value. The later is merely for convenience.

Example
// Get the value of user.id
_ddm.get("user.id");

// Get the value of cart and if it does not exist, create it as an empty array
_ddm.get("cart", [], true);
Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Default Description
path string

The dot notated path to the object/property that you want to retrieve
defaultValue object <optional>

An optional defaultValue that you want to use if no object/property is available at the provided path.
createNonExisting boolean <optional>
 false

Determines if the object/property should be added to DigitalData, using the defaultValue, if it does not exist.
Returns:

Either the value at the path, the defaultValue when provided or undefined if the value does not exist.

Type
object

set(path, value, persistopt, ttlopt) → {*}

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 69

Stores an object at a given dot notated path. If an object already exists at the given path, the provided data will be merged with the existing object. Existing properties with the same name will be overwritten.

Example
// Store a value in DD
_ddm.set("dot.notated.path", "value");

// Store a value in DD and make it persisted
_ddm.set("dot.notated.path", "value", true);
Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Default Description
path string

The dot notated path of the object/property that you want to store
value *

The value that you want to store
persist boolean <optional>
 false

Whether to persist this key or not. Defaults to false.
ttl integer <optional>
 30

Number of minutes to persist the value. Defaults to 30 minutes.
Returns:

The object being stored.

Type
*

erase(path)

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 117

Erases an object from the DD at the provided path. Consequently also unpersists possibly persisted objects at the provided path and any path underneath the provided path.

Example
_ddm.erase("dot.notated.path.to.object.that.must.be.erased");
Parameters:
Name Type Description
path string

The path to the object that must be erased

push(path, value) → {array}

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 160

Pushes a value into an array in the DigitalData object. If an array does not exist yet at the given path, or the object/property at the given path is not an array, an array will be created.

If the value you provide is an array, a "concat" will be performed with the data

Example
// Add a value to an array in the DD
_ddm.push("dot.notated.path.to.array", "value-to-push-into-array");
Parameters:
Name Type Description
path string

The dot notated path of the array that you want to push into
value *

The value that you want to push into the array
Returns:

The array being pushed into

Type
array

has(path) → {Boolean}

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 209

Determines whether the DD has a value at the given path.

Example
// Test if the DD has a value for user.id
if(_ddm.has("user.id")) {
    // ... DD has user.id
}

// For an example to use the availabiltiy of a value in DD together with a triggered event,
// see the examples of isTriggered.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
path string

the dot notated path to the object/property that you want to test.
Returns:

Returns true if the value at the given path is not undefined. False otherwise.

Type
Boolean

empty(path)

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 230

Determines whether the object at the given path is null, an empty object/array, an empty string or does not exist at all. Take note that a string consisting of only whitespace is also regarded as empty and that integer values are never regarded as being empty.

Example
// Test if the DD has a user.name that actually has a non-empty value.
if(!_ddm.empty("user.name")) {
    // ... DD has user.name with a non empty value
}
Parameters:
Name Type Description
path string

The dot notated path to the object/property

change(path, onlyInvokeOnChangesopt, handler)

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 260

Adds a "change" listener to the DD. Change listeners are being invoked whenever there is a change in the DD where the path that the listener is interested in is involved. The handler is also invoked when the listener is registered and there is already data in the DD for the path it wants to listen to.

The path is dot notated and can use two types of wildcards. * and **.

Wildcard listeners using * as the wildcard are invoked whenever there is a change on the same node-level as the node that was changed. For instance, a listener on user.* would be invoked whenever user.id or user.firstname would change. It will not be changed for changes in for instance user.address.zipcode.

Wildcard listeners using ** as the wildcard are invoked whenever there is a change on the same node-level as the node that was changed, as well as deeper node levels. For instance, in the previous situation of user.address.zipcode, listeners for user.** will also be invoked.

Example
// Add a change listener on only the user.products key in the DD
_ddm.change("user.products", function(data) {
    // data holds the value of the user.products object
});

// Add a change listener on user.products and any of it's direct children.
_ddm.change("user.products.*", function(data) {
    // ... do something
});

 // Add a change listener on user.products and any of it's children or grandchildren.
_ddm.change("user.products.**", function(data) {
    // ... do something
});

// Add a change listener on user.id, but do not invoke the handler function if the DD already holds a value for user.id. Only invoke the handler when the property user.id changes.
_ddm.change("user.id", true, function(data) {
    // ... do something
});
Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Default Description
path string

Dot notated path
onlyInvokeOnChanges boolean <optional>
 false

Boolean to indicate that the handler should only be invoked when changes occur.
handler function

The handler that has to be invoked

trigger(eventName, payload) → {Boolean}

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 340

This method can be called to trigger an event. It will look up listeners for the provided name (dot notated, wild cards apply) and invoke all listeners that were interested in the event. The listeners will recieve an event object, which consists of the provided payload.

Example
// Trigger an event without a payload
_ddm.trigger("name-of-event");

// Trigger an event and provide some event data. Handlers of listeners to this event retrieve the data.
_ddm.trigger("name-of-event", {"key": "value"});

// Trigger an event and provide data that needs to be put in DD.
_ddm.trigger("name-of-event", {"dd": {"key", "value"}});
Parameters:
Name Type Description
eventName string

Name of the event (dot notated, wildcards apply)
payload object

The payload of the event. Defaults to an empty object.
Returns:

Returns true if any listeners were invoked, false otherwise.

Type
Boolean

isTriggered(name) → {boolean}

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 478

This function determines if an event with a given name has been triggered before. Returns true if it was, false otherwise.

Example
// Check if an event with the name "myEvent" has been triggered.
if(_ddm.isTriggered("myName")) {
    // ... do something.
}

// Using isTriggered() in combination with has(). This way you can define code that depends on the condition that
// the DD has a value for something AND an event has been triggered.

// Define the handler function as a non-anonymous function.
var handler = function(data) {
    if(_ddm.isTriggered("jquery.loaded") && _ddm.has("session.isp")) {
        // ... do something when the jquery.loaded event was triggered AND the DD has a value/object at session.isp.
    }
};

// And then use the same handler for both an event-listener and a change-listener. Be sure to also listen for historical events (true as 2nd parameter)
_ddm.listen("jquery.loaded", true, handler);
_ddm.change("session.isp", handler);
Parameters:
Name Type Description
name string

The name of the event
Returns:

True or false depending on whether the event with the given name was triggered before.

Type
boolean

listen(name, invokeHandlerOnHistoricalEventsopt, handler, id)

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 519

Adds a event listener. These listeners are being called when the trigger() method is being called and the name of the listener matches the name that was provided to the trigger. This can be used as a general event mechanism. The name is in fact a dot notated path and the same wildcards as for change listeners apply.

By default, the handler function will be called for historical events as well.

It is possible to provide multiple eventnames as an array. All the events in the array must have been triggered before the handler is being called.

By returning true in the handler function DDM will mark the handler as an "execute once" handler and will never call the handler again, unless the same handler function is used by a different listener registration.

Example
// Listen to the "dd.loaded" event
_ddm.listen("dd.loaded", function(e) {
    // ... do something
});

// Listen to the "dd.loaded" event but only invoke the handler function for future events, not historical events.
_ddm.listen("dd.loaded", false, function(e) {
    // ... do something
});

// Listen to the "dd.loaded" event and return true, which indicates to DDM that it should never call this handler again.
_ddm.listen("dd.loaded", function(e) {
    // ... do something
    return true;
});
Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Default Description
name string | Array.<string>

Name of event(s) to listen to (dot notated, wildcards apply)
invokeHandlerOnHistoricalEvents boolean <optional>
 true

Boolean that indicates if the handler should also be invoked for historical events.
handler function

The handler that has to be invoked
id string

The identifier given to this handler. This is used for error handling to aid in debugging.

unlisten(name, handler)

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 654

Removes a listener for a given name. This can not be used for listeners that have been registered using _ddm.listen() with an anonymous function declaration. A reference to the function is required. See examples.

Example
// Create a non-anonymous handler function (Only non-anonymous functions can be unregistered using _ddm.unlisten)
var myHandler = function(e) {
    // ... do something
}
// Register the handler function as a listener to events with the name "myEvent"
_ddm.listen("myEvent", myHandler);

// Unregister the handler to stop listening for events with the name "myEvent"
_ddm.unlisten("myEvent", myHandler);
Parameters:
Name Type Description
name string

Name of an event to remove the listener for (dot notated, wildcards apply)
handler function

The handler that was to be invoked

persist(path, ttlopt)

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 686

Registers a dot-notated path of the DD as persistent. A TTL can be provided in minutes how long the value should be persisted. Defaults to 30 minutes.

This method is also called during the initialization of DDM to register the default paths that are to be persisted.

Example
// Register the "user" key to be persisted
_ddm.persist("user");

// Register the "products" key to be persisted for 60 minutes
_ddm.persist("user", 60);
Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Default Description
path string

dot-notated path into the DD
ttl integer <optional>
 30

Expiration in minutes

unpersist(path)

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 738

Unpersists a given path and removes any change listeners.

Example
// Unpersist the user key
_ddm.unpersist("user");
Parameters:
Name Type Description
path string

Dot-notated path to unpersist

setCookie(name, value, days, pathopt, domainopt)

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 759

Sets a cookie with the given name and value. If a value is specified for days an expiry valye will be set for the cookie. The path of the cookie is defaulted to "/".

Example
// Create a cookie, valid across the entire site
_ddm.setCookie('name', 'value');

// Create a cookie that expires 7 days from now, valid across the entire site
_ddm.setCookie('name', 'value', 7);

// Create a cookie that expires 7 days from now, valid to the path of the current page
_ddm.setCookie('name', 'value', 7, '' });
Parameters:
Name Type Attributes Default Description
name string

The name of the cookie to set.
value string

The value of the cookie to set.
days integer

The number of days until the cookie expires.
path string <optional>
 /

The path of the cookie. Defaults to "/"
domain string <optional>
 .currentdomain.com

The domain of the cookie. Defaults to the base of the current domain, including subdomains (leading dot), eg: .example.com

getCookie(cookieName) → {string}

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 808

Gets a cookie with a given name.

Example
// Get a cookie with the name "userid"
_ddm.getCookie("userid");
Parameters:
Name Type Description
cookieName string

The name of the cookie.
Returns:

The value of the cookie. Undefined if the cookie does not exist.

Type
string

removeCookie(name)

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 852

Removes a cookie with the given name.

Example
// Delete cookie
_ddm.removecookie("name");

// Delete cookie for a given path
_ddm.removecookie("name", "/path");
Parameters:
Name Type Description
name string

The name of the cookie to remove.

cookieExists(name) → {string}

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 870

Checks if a cookie exists.

Example
// Check if a cookie with the name "userid" exists
if(_ddm.cookieExists("userid")) {
    // ... do something
}
Parameters:
Name Type Description
name string

The name of the cookie.
Returns:

True if a cookie with the given name exists. False otherwise.

Type
string

getUrlParam(paramName) → {string}

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 888

Returns the value of a parameter in the HTTP URL string of the current URL.

Example
// Retrieve the userid parameter (With an example URL query string of ?userid=123&product=tv)
var userid = _ddm.getUrlParam("userid");
Parameters:
Name Type Description
paramName string

The name of the parameter to search for.
Returns:

The value of the parameter or an empty string if the parameter does not exist.

Type
string

getRefParam(paramName) → {string}

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 904

Returns the value of a parameter in the HTTP Referer URL string.

Example
// Retrieve the parameter named "productId" from the URL string of the refering page.
_ddm.getRefParam("productId");
Parameters:
Name Type Description
paramName string

The name of the parameter to search for.
Returns:

The value of the parameter or an empty string if the parameter does not exist.

Type
string

isObject(obj) → {Boolean}

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 920

Checks whether a given object is in fact an Object

Example
// Initialize an object
var obj = {};

// Test if it is an object
if(_ddm.isObject(obj)) {
    // ... this will be executed as obj is indeed an object.
}
Parameters:
Name Type Description
obj *

The object to test
Returns:

True or false if the object is in fact an object.

Type
Boolean

cloneObject(obj)

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 1020

Method to clone an object using JSON (de)serialization.

Example
// Create object B as a clone of object a
var a = { "key": "value" };
var b = _ddm.cloneObject(a);

// ... B is now a clone of A. The objects are independent of another so changing properties in A does not change object B and vice versa.
Parameters:
Name Type Description
obj object

The object to clone.

mergeObjects(destination, source) → {object}

Source:
  • ddm.js, line 1439

Deep merge a source object into a destination object, modifying the destination object.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
destination object

The destination object where to merge into.
source object

The source object that needs to be merged into the destination object.
Returns:

The destination object

Type
object
